Is Score Matching Suitable for Estimating Point Processes?

Haoqun Cao1, Zizhuo Meng2, Tianjun Ke1, Feng Zhou1,3
1Center for Applied Statistics and School of Statistics, Renmin University of China
2Data Science Institute, University of Technology Sydney
3Beijing Advanced Innovation Center for Future Blockchain and Privacy Computing
hcao65@wisc.edu, feng.zhou@ruc.edu.cn Corresponding author.
Abstract

Score matching estimators have gained widespread attention in recent years partly because they are free from calculating the integral of normalizing constant, thereby addressing the computational challenges in maximum likelihood estimation (MLE). Some existing works have proposed score matching estimators for point processes. However, this work demonstrates that the incompleteness of the estimators proposed in those works renders them applicable only to specific problems, and they fail for more general point processes. To address this issue, this work introduces the weighted score matching estimator to point processes. Theoretically, we prove the consistency of our estimator and establish its rate of convergence. Experimental results indicate that our estimator accurately estimates model parameters on synthetic data and yields results consistent with MLE on real data. In contrast, existing score matching estimators fail to perform effectively. Codes are publicly available at https://github.com/KenCao2007/WSM_TPP.

1 Introduction

Point processes are a class of statistical models used to characterize event occurrences. Typical models include Poisson processes [9] and Hawkes processes [3]. Their applications span various fields such as seismology [16; 17], finance [1; 4], criminology [15], and neuroscience [11; 26]. In the field of point processes, maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) has been a conventional estimator. However, MLE has an inherent limitation: it requires the computation of the normalizing constant, which corresponds to the intensity integral term in the likelihood. Except for simple cases, calculating the intensity integral analytically is generally infeasible. This necessitates the use of numerical integration methods like Monte Carlo or quadrature for approximating the computation. This introduces approximation errors, and more importantly, for high-dimensional problems, numerical integration encounters the curse of dimensionality, rendering training infeasible.

To address this issue, prior research has introduced the concept of score matching (SM) [5] to the field of point processes. For instance, [18] derived the application of SM to the estimation of traditional statistical Poisson processes. Furthermore, [24] extended the use of SM to the estimation of deep covariate spatio-temporal point processes. [10] also generalized the application of SM to Hawkes processes. These works have greatly advanced the utilization of SM for point processes. However, in practical applications, we have found that these estimators only work for specific point processes. For more general cases, these estimators cannot accurately estimate model parameters, even for some simple statistical point processes. One of the core contribution of this work is to theoretically demonstrate the incompleteness of the estimators proposed in the aforementioned studies.

The incompleteness of the estimators in the aforementioned studies stems from the transition from explicit SM to implicit SM. The explicit SM estimates model parameters by minimizing the expected distance between the gradient of the log-density of the model and the gradient of the log-density of the data. However, we cannot directly minimize the above objective function since it depends on the unknown data distribution. To facilitate solving, we need to convert the above explicit SM to implicit SM by using a trick of integration by parts, provided that some regularity conditions are satisfied [5]. In [18; 24; 10], they assume that the required regularity conditions are satisfied in their point process models and directly employ the implicit SM objective. However, as demonstrated in Section 3, the required regularity conditions cannot be met for general point processes. This implies that the concise implicit SM objectives (Equation (2) in [18], Equation (10) in [24], Equation (4) in [10]) are incomplete, and they cannot accurately estimate parameters for general point processes.

To address this issue, this work introduces a (autoregressive) weighted score matching (WSM) estimator that can be applied to more general point processes. WSM eliminates the intractable terms in SM objective by adding a weight function that takes zero at the boundary of the integration region. Compared to previous work on WSM [6; 22; 12], we are the first work to apply WSM on a stochastic process where the dimension NTsubscript𝑁𝑇N_{T}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is also random. This stochasticity in dimensionality poses greater challenges to the derivation, requiring special treatment to address this issue.

Specifically, we make following contributions: (1) We theoretically demonstrate that implicit (autoregressive) SM estimators in [18; 24; 10] are incomplete because the required regularity conditions cannot be satisfied for general point processes. (2) To address this issue, we propose a (autoregressive) WSM estimator that is applicable to general point processes. Theoretically, we establish its consistency and convergence rate. (3) In experiments, we confirm that on synthetic data, (autoregressive) WSM successfully recovers the ground-truth parameters; on real data, (autoregressive) WSM estimates results consistent with MLE; while existing (autoregressive) SM estimator fails in both scenarios.

2 Preliminaries

Now we provide knowledge on Poisson and Hawkes processes and (autoregressive) score matching.

2.1 Poisson Process and Hawkes Process

The Poisson process [9] is a stochastic point process that models the occurrence of events over a time window [0,T]0𝑇[0,T][ 0 , italic_T ]. A trajectory from Poisson process can be represented as an ordered sequence 𝒯=(t1,…,tNT)𝒯subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡subscript𝑁𝑇\mathcal{T}=(t_{1},\ldots,t_{N_{T}})caligraphic_T = ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where Nt=max⁡{n:tn≤t,t∈[0,T]}subscript𝑁𝑡:𝑛formulae-sequencesubscript𝑡𝑛𝑡𝑡0𝑇N_{t}=\max\{n:t_{n}\leq t,t\in[0,T]\}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_max { italic_n : italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_t , italic_t ∈ [ 0 , italic_T ] } is the corresponding counting process and thus NTsubscript𝑁𝑇N_{T}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the random number of events in [0,T]0𝑇[0,T][ 0 , italic_T ]. The inhomogeneous Poisson process has a time-varying intensity λ⁢(t)𝜆𝑡\lambda(t)italic_λ ( italic_t ) representing the instantaneous rate of event occurrence at t𝑡titalic_t. Mathematically, the intensity function is defined as λ⁢(t)=limδt→0𝔼⁢[Nt+δt−Nt]/δt𝜆𝑡subscript→subscript𝛿𝑡0𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝑡subscript𝛿𝑡subscript𝑁𝑡subscript𝛿𝑡\lambda(t)=\lim_{\delta_{t}\to 0}\mathbb{E}[N_{t+\delta_{t}}-N_{t}]/\delta_{t}italic_λ ( italic_t ) = roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] / italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The probability density function of Poisson process is:

p⁢(𝒯)=∏n=1NTλ⁢(tn)⁢exp⁡(−∫0Tλ⁢(t)⁢𝑑t).𝑝𝒯superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑇𝜆subscript𝑡𝑛superscriptsubscript0𝑇𝜆𝑡differential-d𝑡p(\mathcal{T})=\prod_{n=1}^{N_{T}}\lambda(t_{n})\exp\left(-\int_{0}^{T}\lambda% (t)dt\right).italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_exp ( - ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ ( italic_t ) italic_d italic_t ) . (1)

The Hawkes process [3] is a self-excitation point process where the occurrence of an event increases the likelihood of more events in the future. A trajectory from Hawkes process is similarly represented as 𝒯=(t1,…,tNT)𝒯subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡subscript𝑁𝑇\mathcal{T}=(t_{1},\ldots,t_{N_{T}})caligraphic_T = ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) on [0,T]0𝑇[0,T][ 0 , italic_T ]. The conditional intensity function of Hawkes process, representing the instantaneous rate of event occurrence at t𝑡titalic_t given the history up to but not including t𝑡titalic_t, is:

λ∗⁢(t)=λ⁢(t|ℱt−)=μ⁢(t)+∑tj<tg⁢(t−tj),superscript𝜆𝑡𝜆conditional𝑡subscriptℱsuperscript𝑡𝜇𝑡subscriptsubscript𝑡𝑗𝑡𝑔𝑡subscript𝑡𝑗\lambda^{*}(t)=\lambda(t|\mathcal{F}_{t^{-}})=\mu(t)+\sum_{t_{j}<t}g(t-t_{j}),italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = italic_λ ( italic_t | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_μ ( italic_t ) + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g ( italic_t - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (2)

where μ⁢(t)𝜇𝑡\mu(t)italic_μ ( italic_t ) is the baseline intensity, g⁢(⋅)𝑔⋅g(\cdot)italic_g ( ⋅ ) is the triggering kernel representing the self-excitation effect, the summation expresses the accumulative excitation from all past events, ℱt−subscriptℱsuperscript𝑡\mathcal{F}_{t^{-}}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the historical information up to but not including t𝑡titalic_t. λ∗⁢(t)superscript𝜆𝑡\lambda^{*}(t)italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) means the intensity is dependent on the history.

Poisson process assumes the independence of event occurrences, while Hawkes process extends it by introducing an autoregressive structure, making subsequent events dependent on prior events. Given the history ℱtn=(t1,…,tn)subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡𝑛\mathcal{F}_{t_{n}}=(t_{1},\ldots,t_{n})caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the conditional probability density of (n+1)𝑛1(n+1)( italic_n + 1 )-th event at t>tn𝑡subscript𝑡𝑛t>t_{n}italic_t > italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is:

p⁢(t|ℱtn)=λ∗⁢(t)⁢exp⁡(−∫tntλ∗⁢(τ)⁢𝑑τ).𝑝conditional𝑡subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛superscript𝜆𝑡superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑡𝑛𝑡superscript𝜆𝜏differential-d𝜏p(t|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n}})=\lambda^{*}(t)\exp\left(-\int_{t_{n}}^{t}\lambda^{*}(% \tau)d\tau\right).italic_p ( italic_t | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) roman_exp ( - ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) italic_d italic_τ ) . (3)

Here, we introduce the definition of the univariate Hawkes process. However, multivariate Hawkes processes also exist. For ease of notation, we use the univariate case for illustration, but we also provide solutions for the multivariate case.

2.2 Score Matching

MLE is a classic estimator that minimizes Kullback–Leibler divergence between a model distribution and data distribution. However, a drawback is the intractable computation of the normalizing constant. Approximating it through numerical integration can be computationally demanding. In contrast, SM [5] offers an alternative by minimizing Fisher divergence between model and data distributions:

ℒSM⁢(θ)=12⁢𝔼p⁢(𝐱)⁢‖∇𝐱log⁡p⁢(𝐱)−∇𝐱log⁡pθ⁢(𝐱)‖2,subscriptℒSM𝜃12subscript𝔼𝑝𝐱superscriptnormsubscript∇𝐱𝑝𝐱subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝜃𝐱2\mathcal{L}_{\text{SM}}(\theta)=\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}_{p(\mathbf{x})}\|\nabla_% {\mathbf{x}}\log p(\mathbf{x})-\nabla_{\mathbf{x}}\log p_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})% \|^{2},caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT SM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_x ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( bold_x ) - ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where p⁢(𝐱)𝑝𝐱p(\mathbf{x})italic_p ( bold_x ) represents the data distribution, pθ⁢(𝐱)subscript𝑝𝜃𝐱p_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) is the parameterized model distribution, the gradient of the log-density is called the score, and ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\|∥ ⋅ ∥ represents a suitable norm, such as the ℓ2superscriptℓ2\ell^{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT norm. Minimizing the Fisher divergence above provides the parameter estimate. The advantage of SM lies in its ability to bypass the computation of the normalizing constant since the score no longer contains this constant: pθ⁢(𝐱)=1Z⁢(θ)⁢p~θ⁢(𝐱)subscript𝑝𝜃𝐱1𝑍𝜃subscript~𝑝𝜃𝐱p_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{Z(\theta)}\tilde{p}_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z ( italic_θ ) end_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) where Z⁢(θ)=∫p~θ⁢(𝐱)⁢𝑑𝐱𝑍𝜃subscript~𝑝𝜃𝐱differential-d𝐱Z(\theta)=\int\tilde{p}_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})d\mathbf{x}italic_Z ( italic_θ ) = ∫ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) italic_d bold_x, ∇𝐱log⁡pθ⁢(𝐱)=∇𝐱log⁡p~θ⁢(𝐱)subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝜃𝐱subscript∇𝐱subscript~𝑝𝜃𝐱\nabla_{\mathbf{x}}\log p_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})=\nabla_{\mathbf{x}}\log\tilde{p% }_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) = ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ).

Under certain conditions, we can use integration by parts to replace the explicit SM objective, which involves an unknown distribution p⁢(𝐱)𝑝𝐱p(\mathbf{x})italic_p ( bold_x ), with an equivalent implicit one,

𝒥SM⁢(θ)=𝔼p⁢(𝐱)⁢[12⁢‖∇𝐱log⁡pθ⁢(𝐱)‖2+Tr⁢(∇𝐱2log⁡pθ⁢(𝐱))].subscript𝒥SM𝜃subscript𝔼𝑝𝐱delimited-[]12superscriptnormsubscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝜃𝐱2Trsubscriptsuperscript∇2𝐱subscript𝑝𝜃𝐱\mathcal{J}_{\text{SM}}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{p(\mathbf{x})}\left[\frac{1}{2}\|% \nabla_{\mathbf{x}}\log p_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})\|^{2}+\text{Tr}\left(\nabla^{2}% _{\mathbf{x}}\log p_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})\right)\right].caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT SM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_x ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + Tr ( ∇ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) ] . (4)

2.3 Autoregressive Score Matching

An autoregressive model defines a probability density p⁢(𝐱)𝑝𝐱p(\mathbf{x})italic_p ( bold_x ) as a product of conditionals using the chain rule: p⁢(𝐱)=∏n=1Np⁢(xn|𝐱<n)𝑝𝐱superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑛1𝑁𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝐱absent𝑛p(\mathbf{x})=\prod_{n=1}^{N}p(x_{n}|\mathbf{x}_{<n})italic_p ( bold_x ) = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where xnsubscript𝑥𝑛x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the n𝑛nitalic_n-th entry and 𝐱<nsubscript𝐱absent𝑛\mathbf{x}_{<n}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the entries with indices smaller than n𝑛nitalic_n. The original SM is not suitable for autoregressive models because the autoregressive structure introduces challenges in gradient computation in Equation 4. To address this issue, [13] proposed autoregressive score matching (ASM). Unlike SM, which minimizes the Fisher divergence between the joint distributions of the model pθ⁢(𝐱)subscript𝑝𝜃𝐱p_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) and the data p⁢(𝐱)𝑝𝐱p(\mathbf{x})italic_p ( bold_x ), ASM minimizes the Fisher divergence between the conditionals of the model pθ⁢(xn|𝐱<n)subscript𝑝𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝐱absent𝑛p_{\theta}(x_{n}|\mathbf{x}_{<n})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and the data p⁢(xn|𝐱<n)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝐱absent𝑛p(x_{n}|\mathbf{x}_{<n})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ):

ℒASM⁢(θ)=12⁢∑n=1N𝔼p⁢(𝐱≤n)⁢(∂log⁡p⁢(xn|𝐱<n)∂xn−∂log⁡pθ⁢(xn|𝐱<n)∂xn)2.subscriptℒASM𝜃12superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝔼𝑝subscript𝐱absent𝑛superscript𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝐱absent𝑛subscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝑝𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝐱absent𝑛subscript𝑥𝑛2\mathcal{L}_{\text{ASM}}(\theta)=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\mathbb{E}_{p(% \mathbf{x}_{\leq n})}\left(\frac{\partial\log p(x_{n}|\mathbf{x}_{<n})}{% \partial x_{n}}-\frac{\partial\log p_{\theta}(x_{n}|\mathbf{x}_{<n})}{\partial x% _{n}}\right)^{2}.caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ASM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG ∂ roman_log italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - divide start_ARG ∂ roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Similarly, the above explicit ASM objective involves an unknown distribution p⁢(xn|𝐱<n)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝐱absent𝑛p(x_{n}|\mathbf{x}_{<n})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Under specific regularity conditions, we can apply integration by parts to derive an implicit ASM objective:

𝒥ASM⁢(θ)=∑n=1N𝔼p⁢(𝐱≤n)⁢[12⁢(∂log⁡pθ⁢(xn|𝐱<n)∂xn)2+∂2log⁡pθ⁢(xn|𝐱<n)∂xn2].subscript𝒥ASM𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝔼𝑝subscript𝐱absent𝑛delimited-[]12superscriptsubscript𝑝𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝐱absent𝑛subscript𝑥𝑛2superscript2subscript𝑝𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝐱absent𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛2\mathcal{J}_{\text{ASM}}(\theta)=\sum_{n=1}^{N}\mathbb{E}_{p(\mathbf{x}_{\leq n% })}\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial\log p_{\theta}(x_{n}|\mathbf{x}_{<n})% }{\partial x_{n}}\right)^{2}+\frac{\partial^{2}\log p_{\theta}(x_{n}|\mathbf{x% }_{<n})}{\partial x_{n}^{2}}\right].caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ASM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG ∂ roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG ∂ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ] . (5)

3 Score Matching for Poisson Process

We analyze the application of SM for Poisson process and its failure in achieving consistent estimation. Subsequently, we propose a provably consistent WSM estimator.

3.1 Failure of Score Matching for Poisson Process

Consider a Poisson process 𝒯=(t1,…,tNT)𝒯subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡subscript𝑁𝑇\mathcal{T}=(t_{1},\ldots,t_{N_{T}})caligraphic_T = ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) on [0,T]0𝑇[0,T][ 0 , italic_T ]. Let p⁢(𝒯)𝑝𝒯p(\mathcal{T})italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) represent the data distribution, which is uniquely associated with an intensity function λ⁢(t)𝜆𝑡\lambda(t)italic_λ ( italic_t ). Let pθ⁢(𝒯)subscript𝑝𝜃𝒯p_{\theta}(\mathcal{T})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) represent the parameterized model distribution, which is uniquely associated with a parameterized intensity function λθ⁢(t)subscript𝜆𝜃𝑡\lambda_{\theta}(t)italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ). In the following, we denote the score as ψ⁢(tn)=∂∂tn⁢log⁡p⁢(𝒯)𝜓subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑡𝑛𝑝𝒯\psi(t_{n})=\frac{\partial}{\partial t_{n}}\log p(\mathcal{T})italic_ψ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG ∂ end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log italic_p ( caligraphic_T ).

Previous works [18; 24] have both attempted to apply SM to the Poisson process:

ℒSM⁢(θ)=12⁢𝔼p⁢(𝒯)⁢[∑n=1NT(ψ⁢(tn)−ψθ⁢(tn))2].subscriptℒSM𝜃12subscript𝔼𝑝𝒯delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑇superscript𝜓subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝜓𝜃subscript𝑡𝑛2\mathcal{L}_{\text{SM}}(\theta)=\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}_{p(\mathcal{T})}\left[% \sum_{n=1}^{N_{T}}\left(\psi(t_{n})-\psi_{\theta}(t_{n})\right)^{2}\right].caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT SM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ψ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] . (6)

In order for SM to be practical, [18; 24] assumed that specific regularity conditions are satisfied. Therefore, they employed an implicit SM objective similar to Equation 4:

𝒥SM⁢(θ)=𝔼p⁢(𝒯)⁢[∑n=1NT12⁢ψθ2⁢(tn)+∂ψ⁢(tn)∂tn].subscript𝒥SM𝜃subscript𝔼𝑝𝒯delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑇12subscriptsuperscript𝜓2𝜃subscript𝑡𝑛𝜓subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑡𝑛\mathcal{J}_{\text{SM}}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{p(\mathcal{T})}\left[\sum_{n=1}^{N% _{T}}\frac{1}{2}\psi^{2}_{\theta}(t_{n})+\frac{\partial\psi(t_{n})}{\partial t% _{n}}\right].caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT SM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_ψ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG ∂ italic_ψ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ] . (7)

In practical applications, we have found that the above estimator works only for specific Poisson processes and fails for more general Poisson processes. The reason for its failure lies in the fact that, for more general Poisson processes, the specific regularity conditions cannot be satisfied.

Such conditions require the probability density function of the random variable is zero when it approaches infinity in any of its dimensions. However, for point processes, such requirement is not satisfied, because the random variable in point process 𝒯=(t1,…,tNT)𝒯subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡subscript𝑁𝑇\mathcal{T}=(t_{1},\ldots,t_{N_{T}})caligraphic_T = ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is not of fixed dimension and takes values in a subset of ℝ+NTsuperscriptsubscriptℝsubscript𝑁𝑇\mathbb{R}_{+}^{N_{T}}blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, for general Poisson processes, we cannot derive the implicit SM in Equation 7 based on the explicit SM in Equation 6.

Proposition 3.1.

Assume that all functions and expectations in ℒSM⁢(θ)subscriptℒSM𝜃\mathcal{L}_{\text{SM}}(\theta)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT SM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) and 𝒥SM⁢(θ)subscript𝒥SM𝜃\mathcal{J}_{\text{SM}}(\theta)caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT SM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) are well defined, we have,

ℒSM⁢(θ)=subscriptℒSM𝜃absent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{SM}}(\theta)=caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT SM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = 𝒥SM⁢(θ)+const−∑N=1∞∫p⁢(t1,…,tN)⁢∂log⁡pθ⁢(t1,…,tN)∂t1|t1=0⁢d⁢𝒯2:Nsubscript𝒥SM𝜃constevaluated-atsuperscriptsubscript𝑁1𝑝subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡𝑁subscript𝑝𝜃subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡𝑁subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡10𝑑subscript𝒯:2𝑁\displaystyle\mathcal{J}_{\text{SM}}(\theta)+\text{const}-\sum_{N=1}^{\infty}% \int p(t_{1},\ldots,t_{N})\frac{\partial\log p_{\theta}(t_{1},\ldots,t_{N})}{% \partial t_{1}}\Big{|}_{t_{1}=0}d\mathcal{T}_{2:N}caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT SM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) + const - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG ∂ roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 : italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (8)
+∑N=1∞∫p⁢(t1,…,tN)⁢∂log⁡pθ⁢(t1,…,tN)∂tN|tN=T⁢d⁢𝒯1:N−1.evaluated-atsuperscriptsubscript𝑁1𝑝subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡𝑁subscript𝑝𝜃subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡𝑁subscript𝑡𝑁subscript𝑡𝑁𝑇𝑑subscript𝒯:1𝑁1\displaystyle+\sum_{N=1}^{\infty}\int p(t_{1},\ldots,t_{N})\frac{\partial\log p% _{\theta}(t_{1},\ldots,t_{N})}{\partial t_{N}}\Big{|}_{t_{N}=T}d\mathcal{T}_{1% :N-1}.+ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG ∂ roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_N - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Therefore, ℒSM⁢(θ)subscriptℒSM𝜃\mathcal{L}_{\text{SM}}(\theta)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT SM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) is equivalent to 𝒥SM⁢(θ)subscript𝒥SM𝜃\mathcal{J}_{\text{SM}}(\theta)caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT SM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) if and only if the sum of the last two terms is a constant not containing θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ.

For specific Poisson processes, the sum of the last two terms can be zero. However, for more general cases, this sum contains θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ. This implies that 𝒥SMsubscript𝒥SM\mathcal{J}_{\text{SM}}caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT SM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT fails for general Poisson processes.

3.2 Weighted Score Matching

To address the situation where SM fails, inspired by [6; 22], we introduce the WSM for Poisson process. The core idea of WSM is to eliminate the two intractable terms by adding a weight function that takes zero at the boundary of the integration region. The weight function is designed to be a vector-valued function 𝐡:ℝ+NT→ℝ+NT:𝐡→subscriptsuperscriptℝsubscript𝑁𝑇superscriptsubscriptℝsubscript𝑁𝑇\mathbf{h}:\mathbb{R}^{N_{T}}_{+}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+}^{N_{T}}bold_h : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with the n𝑛nitalic_n-th element denoted as hn⁢(𝒯)subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯h_{n}(\mathcal{T})italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ). Here, we present the conditions that a valid weight function should satisfy:

limtn→tn+1p⁢(𝒯)⁢ψθ⁢(tn)⁢hn⁢(𝒯)=0,limtn→tn−1p⁢(𝒯)⁢ψθ⁢(tn)⁢hn⁢(𝒯)=0,∀n∈[NT],𝔼⁢[ψθ2⁢(tn)⁢hn⁢(𝒯)]<∞,𝔼⁢[ψθ⁢(tn)⁢∂hn⁢(𝒯)∂tn]<∞,∀n∈[NT].formulae-sequencesubscript→subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑡𝑛1𝑝𝒯subscript𝜓𝜃subscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯0formulae-sequencesubscript→subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑡𝑛1𝑝𝒯subscript𝜓𝜃subscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯0formulae-sequencefor-all𝑛delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝑇formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝜓2𝜃subscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜓𝜃subscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯subscript𝑡𝑛for-all𝑛delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝑇\begin{gathered}\lim_{t_{n}\rightarrow t_{n+1}}p(\mathcal{T})\psi_{\theta}(t_{% n})h_{n}(\mathcal{T})=0,\ \lim_{t_{n}\rightarrow t_{n-1}}p(\mathcal{T})\psi_{% \theta}(t_{n})h_{n}(\mathcal{T})=0,\ \forall n\in[N_{T}],\\ \mathbb{E}[\psi^{2}_{\theta}(t_{n})h_{n}(\mathcal{T})]<\infty,\ \mathbb{E}[% \psi_{\theta}(t_{n})\frac{\partial h_{n}(\mathcal{T})}{\partial t_{n}}]<\infty% ,\forall n\in[N_{T}].\end{gathered}start_ROW start_CELL roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) = 0 , roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) = 0 , ∀ italic_n ∈ [ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_E [ italic_ψ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) ] < ∞ , blackboard_E [ italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG ∂ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ] < ∞ , ∀ italic_n ∈ [ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] . end_CELL end_ROW (9)

One can verify that such weight functions are easy to find for most p⁢(𝒯)𝑝𝒯p(\mathcal{T})italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) and ψθ⁢(tn)subscript𝜓𝜃subscript𝑡𝑛\psi_{\theta}(t_{n})italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). With a valid weight function 𝐡𝐡\mathbf{h}bold_h, the explicit WSM objective can be defined as:

ℒWSM⁢(θ)=12⁢𝔼p⁢(𝒯)⁢[∑n=1NT(ψ⁢(tn)−ψθ⁢(tn))2⁢hn⁢(𝒯)].subscriptℒWSM𝜃12subscript𝔼𝑝𝒯delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑇superscript𝜓subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝜓𝜃subscript𝑡𝑛2subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{WSM}}(\theta)=\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}_{p(% \mathcal{T})}\left[\sum_{n=1}^{N_{T}}(\psi(t_{n})-\psi_{\theta}(t_{n}))^{2}h_{% n}(\mathcal{T})\right].caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT WSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ψ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) ] . (10)

The introduction of the weight function allows control over the values of the integrand at the boundaries of the integration domain, thereby eliminating the last two terms in Equation 8.

Theorem 3.2.

Assume the true intensity is in the family of the model intensity, denoted as λ⁢(t)=λθ∗⁢(t)𝜆𝑡subscript𝜆superscript𝜃𝑡\lambda(t)=\lambda_{\theta^{*}}(t)italic_λ ( italic_t ) = italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ), where θ∗∈Θsuperscript𝜃Θ\theta^{*}\in\Thetaitalic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ roman_Θ. We further assume that ∂log⁡λθ1⁢(t)∂t=∂log⁡λθ2⁢(t)∂t⁢a.s.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜆subscript𝜃1𝑡𝑡subscript𝜆subscript𝜃2𝑡𝑡𝑎𝑠\frac{\partial\log\lambda_{\theta_{1}}(t)}{\partial t}=\frac{\partial\log% \lambda_{\theta_{2}}(t)}{\partial t}\ a.s.divide start_ARG ∂ roman_log italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t end_ARG = divide start_ARG ∂ roman_log italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t end_ARG italic_a . italic_s . gives θ1=θ2subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2\theta_{1}=\theta_{2}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then the unique minimizer of ℒWSM⁢(θ)subscriptℒWSM𝜃\mathcal{L}_{\text{WSM}}(\theta)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT WSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) is θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

The explicit WSM objective is not practical as it depends on the unknown data distribution p⁢(𝒯)𝑝𝒯p(\mathcal{T})italic_p ( caligraphic_T ), so we further derive the implicit WSM objective which is tractable.

Theorem 3.3.

Assume that all functions and expectations in ℒWSM⁢(θ)subscriptℒWSM𝜃\mathcal{L}_{\text{WSM}}(\theta)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT WSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) and 𝒥WSM⁢(θ)subscript𝒥WSM𝜃\mathcal{J}_{\text{WSM}}(\theta)caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT WSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) are well defined, Equation 9 is satisfied, we have,

ℒWSM⁢(θ)=𝒥WSM⁢(θ)+const,subscriptℒWSM𝜃subscript𝒥WSM𝜃const\mathcal{L}_{\text{WSM}}(\theta)=\mathcal{J}_{\text{WSM}}(\theta)+\text{const},caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT WSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT WSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) + const ,
𝒥WSM⁢(θ)=𝔼p⁢(𝒯)⁢[∑n=1NT12⁢ψθ2⁢(tn)⁢hn⁢(𝒯)+∂ψθ⁢(tn)∂tn⁢hn⁢(𝒯)+ψθ⁢(tn)⁢∂hn⁢(𝒯)∂tn].subscript𝒥WSM𝜃subscript𝔼𝑝𝒯delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑇12subscriptsuperscript𝜓2𝜃subscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯subscript𝜓𝜃subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯subscript𝜓𝜃subscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯subscript𝑡𝑛\displaystyle\mathcal{J}_{\text{WSM}}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{p(\mathcal{T})}\left% [\sum_{n=1}^{N_{T}}\frac{1}{2}\psi^{2}_{\theta}(t_{n})h_{n}(\mathcal{T})+\frac% {\partial\psi_{\theta}(t_{n})}{\partial t_{n}}h_{n}(\mathcal{T})+\psi_{\theta}% (t_{n})\frac{\partial h_{n}(\mathcal{T})}{\partial t_{n}}\right].caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT WSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_ψ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) + divide start_ARG ∂ italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) + italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG ∂ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ] . (11)

For general Poisson processes, Equation 11 is always valid with a suitable weight function. Thus, we do not need to worry about the issues of failure that may arise when using Equation 7.

4 Autoregressive Score Matching for Hawkes Processes

Similarly, we analyze the usage of ASM for Hawkes processes and its failure in achieving consistent estimation. Subsequently, we propose a provably consistent autoregressive WSM (AWSM) estimator.

4.1 Failure of Autoregressive Score Matching for Hawkes Process

The original SM, even when adjusted by a weight function, is not suitable for point processes with autoregressive structures, such as Hawkes process. Because in such cases, directly calculating the score still includes the intensity integral, which is precisely what the use of SM aims to avoid. Therefore, an ASM method is proposed for parameter estimation for Hawkes process in [10].

Consider a Hawkes process 𝒯=(t1,…,tNT)𝒯subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡subscript𝑁𝑇\mathcal{T}=(t_{1},\ldots,t_{N_{T}})caligraphic_T = ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) on [0,T]0𝑇[0,T][ 0 , italic_T ] with the underlying conditional probability density of tnsubscript𝑡𝑛t_{n}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denoted as p⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1p(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). The parameterized conditional probability density model of tnsubscript𝑡𝑛t_{n}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is pθ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)subscript𝑝𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1p_{\theta}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). We denote the conditional score as ψ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)=∂∂tn⁢log⁡p⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)=∂∂tn⁢log⁡λ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)−λ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1),n=1,…⁢NTformulae-sequence𝜓conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝑡𝑛𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝑡𝑛𝜆conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1𝜆conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1𝑛1…subscript𝑁𝑇\psi(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})=\frac{\partial}{\partial t_{n}}\log p(t_{n}|% \mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})=\frac{\partial}{\partial t_{n}}\log\lambda(t_{n}|% \mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})-\lambda(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}}),n=1,\ldots N_{T}italic_ψ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG ∂ end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG ∂ end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log italic_λ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_λ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_n = 1 , … italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. An explicit ASM objective is defined as:

ℒASM⁢(θ)=12⁢𝔼p⁢(𝒯)⁢[∑n=1NT(ψ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)−ψθ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1))2].subscriptℒASM𝜃12subscript𝔼𝑝𝒯delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑇superscript𝜓conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝜓𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛12\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{ASM}}(\theta)=\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}_{p(% \mathcal{T})}\left[\sum_{n=1}^{N_{T}}(\psi(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})-\psi_{% \theta}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}}))^{2}\right].caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ASM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ψ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] . (12)

Similarly, to make ASM practical, [10] assumed that specific regularity conditions are satisfied. Therefore, an implicit ASM is proposed accordingly:

𝒥ASM⁢(θ)=𝔼p⁢(𝒯)⁢[∑n=1NT12⁢ψθ2⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)+∂ψθ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)∂tn].subscript𝒥ASM𝜃subscript𝔼𝑝𝒯delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑇12subscriptsuperscript𝜓2𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝜓𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝑡𝑛\displaystyle\mathcal{J}_{\text{ASM}}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{p(\mathcal{T})}\left% [\sum_{n=1}^{N_{T}}\frac{1}{2}\psi^{2}_{\theta}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})+% \frac{\partial\psi_{\theta}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})}{\partial t_{n}}% \right].caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ASM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_ψ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG ∂ italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ] . (13)

However, the same issue as in the Poisson process arises here. The regularity conditions required to eliminate the unknown data distribution do not hold. Therefore, we cannot derive the implicit ASM in Equation 13 based on the explicit ASM in Equation 12.

Proposition 4.1.

Assume that all functions and expectations in ℒASM⁢(θ)subscriptℒASM𝜃\mathcal{L}_{\text{ASM}}(\theta)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ASM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) and 𝒥ASM⁢(θ)subscript𝒥ASM𝜃\mathcal{J}_{\text{ASM}}(\theta)caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ASM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) are well defined, we have,

ℒASM⁢(θ)=subscriptℒASM𝜃absent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{ASM}}(\theta)=caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ASM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = 𝒥ASM⁢(θ)+const+∑n=1∞∫p⁢(𝒯:n−1)⁢p⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)⁢ψθ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)|tn=T⁢d⁢𝒯:n−1subscript𝒥ASM𝜃constevaluated-atsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑝subscript𝒯:absent𝑛1𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝜓𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝑡𝑛𝑇𝑑subscript𝒯:absent𝑛1\displaystyle\mathcal{J}_{\text{ASM}}(\theta)+\text{const}+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}% \int p(\mathcal{T}_{:n-1})p(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})\psi_{\theta}(t_{n}|% \mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})\Big{|}_{t_{n}=T}d\mathcal{T}_{:{n-1}}caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ASM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) + const + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ italic_p ( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (14)
−\displaystyle-- ∑n=1∞∫p⁢(𝒯:n−1)⁢p⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)⁢ψθ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)|tn=tn−1⁢d⁢𝒯:n−1.evaluated-atsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑝subscript𝒯:absent𝑛1𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝜓𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑡𝑛1𝑑subscript𝒯:absent𝑛1\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\int p(\mathcal{T}_{:n-1})p(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_% {t_{n-1}})\psi_{\theta}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})\Big{|}_{t_{n}=t_{n-1}}d% \mathcal{T}_{:{n-1}}.∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ italic_p ( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Therefore, ℒASM⁢(θ)subscriptℒASM𝜃\mathcal{L}_{\text{ASM}}(\theta)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ASM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) is equivalent to 𝒥ASM⁢(θ)subscript𝒥ASM𝜃\mathcal{J}_{\text{ASM}}(\theta)caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ASM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) if and only if the sum of last two terms is a constant not containing θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ.

Generally speaking, for most Hawkes processes, the sum of the last two terms in Equation 14 still contains θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ, even for a common Hawkes process with an exponential decay triggering kernel. We illustrate this example in Section 6.2. This implies that 𝒥ASMsubscript𝒥ASM\mathcal{J}_{\text{ASM}}caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ASM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT fails for general Hawkes processes.

4.2 Autoregressive Weighted Score Matching

Similarly, to address the situation where ASM fails, we introduce the AWSM for Hawkes process. We present the conditions that a valid weight function 𝐡𝐡\mathbf{h}bold_h should satisfy :

limtn→Tp⁢(𝒯1:n)⁢ψθ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)⁢hn⁢(𝒯)=0,limtn→tn−1p⁢(𝒯1:n)⁢ψθ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)⁢hn⁢(𝒯)=0,∀n∈[NT],formulae-sequencesubscript→subscript𝑡𝑛𝑇𝑝subscript𝒯:1𝑛subscript𝜓𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯0formulae-sequencesubscript→subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑡𝑛1𝑝subscript𝒯:1𝑛subscript𝜓𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯0for-all𝑛delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝑇\displaystyle\lim_{t_{n}\rightarrow T}p(\mathcal{T}_{1:n})\psi_{\theta}(t_{n}|% \mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})h_{n}(\mathcal{T})=0,\lim_{t_{n}\rightarrow t_{n-1}}p(% \mathcal{T}_{1:n})\psi_{\theta}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})h_{n}(\mathcal{T})% =0,\ \forall n\in[N_{T}],roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) = 0 , roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) = 0 , ∀ italic_n ∈ [ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ,
𝔼⁢[ψθ2⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)⁢hn⁢(𝒯)]<∞,𝔼⁢[ψθ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)⁢∂hn⁢(𝒯)∂tn]<∞,∀n∈[NT].formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜓𝜃2conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜓𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯subscript𝑡𝑛for-all𝑛delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝑇\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\psi_{\theta}^{2}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})h_{n}(% \mathcal{T})]<\infty,\ \mathbb{E}[\psi_{\theta}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})% \frac{\partial h_{n}(\mathcal{T})}{\partial t_{n}}]<\infty,\forall n\in[N_{T}].blackboard_E [ italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) ] < ∞ , blackboard_E [ italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG ∂ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ] < ∞ , ∀ italic_n ∈ [ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] . (15)

With a valid weight function 𝐡𝐡\mathbf{h}bold_h, the explicit AWSM objective can be defined as:

ℒAWSM⁢(θ)=12⁢𝔼p⁢(𝒯)⁢[∑n=1NT(ψ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)−ψθ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1))2⁢hn⁢(𝒯)].subscriptℒAWSM𝜃12subscript𝔼𝑝𝒯delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑇superscript𝜓conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝜓𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛12subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{AWSM}}(\theta)=\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}_{p(% \mathcal{T})}\left[\sum_{n=1}^{N_{T}}(\psi(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})-\psi_{% \theta}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}}))^{2}h_{n}(\mathcal{T})\right].caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT AWSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ψ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) ] . (16)
Theorem 4.2.

Assume the true conditional density is in the family of the model conditional density, denoted as p⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)=pθ∗⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝑝superscript𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1p(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})=p_{\theta^{*}}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where θ∗∈Θsuperscript𝜃Θ\theta^{*}\in\Thetaitalic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ roman_Θ. We further assume that pθ1⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)=pθ2⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)⁢a.e.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝subscript𝜃1conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝑝subscript𝜃2conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1𝑎𝑒p_{\theta_{1}}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})=p_{\theta_{2}}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{% t_{n-1}})\ a.e.italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_a . italic_e . gives θ1=θ2subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2\theta_{1}=\theta_{2}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then the unique minimizer of ℒAWSM⁢(θ)subscriptℒAWSM𝜃\mathcal{L}_{\text{AWSM}}(\theta)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT AWSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) is θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

The explicit AWSM objective is not practical as it depends on the unknown data distribution p⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1p(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), so we further derive the implicit AWSM objective which is tractable.

Theorem 4.3.

Assume that all functions and expectations in ℒAWSM⁢(θ)subscriptℒAWSM𝜃\mathcal{L}_{\text{AWSM}}(\theta)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT AWSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) and 𝒥AWSM⁢(θ)subscript𝒥AWSM𝜃\mathcal{J}_{\text{AWSM}}(\theta)caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT AWSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) are well defined, Equation 15 are satisfied, we have,

ℒAWSM⁢(θ)subscriptℒAWSM𝜃\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{AWSM}}(\theta)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT AWSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) =𝒥AWSM⁢(θ)+const,absentsubscript𝒥AWSM𝜃const\displaystyle=\mathcal{J}_{\text{AWSM}}(\theta)+\text{const},= caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT AWSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) + const ,
𝒥AWSM⁢(θ)=𝔼p⁢(𝒯)⁢[∑n=1NT12⁢ψθ2⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)⁢hn⁢(𝒯)+∂ψθ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)∂tn⁢hn⁢(𝒯)+ψθ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)⁢∂hn⁢(𝒯)∂tn].subscript𝒥AWSM𝜃subscript𝔼𝑝𝒯delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑇12subscriptsuperscript𝜓2𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯subscript𝜓𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯subscript𝜓𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯subscript𝑡𝑛\displaystyle\mathcal{J}_{\text{AWSM}}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{p(\mathcal{T})}% \left[\sum_{n=1}^{N_{T}}\frac{1}{2}\psi^{2}_{\theta}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1% }})h_{n}(\mathcal{T})+\frac{\partial\psi_{\theta}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})% }{\partial t_{n}}h_{n}(\mathcal{T})+\psi_{\theta}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})% \frac{\partial h_{n}(\mathcal{T})}{\partial t_{n}}\right].caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT AWSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_ψ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) + divide start_ARG ∂ italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) + italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG ∂ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ] . (17)

For general Hawkes processes, Equation 17 is always valid with a suitable weight function. Thus, we do not need to worry about the issues of failure that may arise when using Equation 13.

Multivariate Hawkes Processes

For the multivariate case, events are {(t1,k1),…,(tNT,kNT)}subscript𝑡1subscript𝑘1…subscript𝑡subscript𝑁𝑇subscript𝑘subscript𝑁𝑇\{(t_{1},k_{1}),\ldots,(t_{N_{T}},k_{N_{T}})\}{ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , … , ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } with kn∈1,…,Ksubscript𝑘𝑛1…𝐾k_{n}\in{1,\ldots,K}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ 1 , … , italic_K denoting the event type of the n𝑛nitalic_n-th event. The history up to the (n−1)𝑛1(n-1)( italic_n - 1 )-th event is denoted by ℱtn−1subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We need to consider both the distributions of event times and event types. For the temporal distribution, we use the AWSM objective with the temporal score ψ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)=∂∂tn⁢log⁡p⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)𝜓conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝑡𝑛𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1\psi(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})=\frac{\partial}{\partial t_{n}}\log p(t_{n}|% \mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})italic_ψ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG ∂ end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) as before. For the type distribution, since we do not need to compute the intensity integral, we directly use the cross-entropy objective:

𝒥CE⁢(θ)=𝔼p⁢(𝒯)⁢[∑n=1NTlog⁡pθ⁢(kn|ℱtn−1,tn)]=𝔼⁢[∑n=1NTlog⁡λkn⁢(tn|ℱtn−1;θ)−log⁡λ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1;θ)],subscript𝒥CE𝜃subscript𝔼𝑝𝒯delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑇subscript𝑝𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑘𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝑡𝑛𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑇subscript𝜆subscript𝑘𝑛conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1𝜃𝜆conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1𝜃\mathcal{J}_{\text{CE}}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{p(\mathcal{T})}\left[\sum_{n=1}^{N% _{T}}\log p_{\theta}(k_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}},t_{n})\right]=\mathbb{E}\left% [\sum_{n=1}^{N_{T}}\log\lambda_{k_{n}}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}};\theta)-% \log\lambda(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}};\theta)\right],caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT CE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = blackboard_E [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_θ ) - roman_log italic_λ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_θ ) ] , (18)

where λ=∑k=1Kλk𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜆𝑘\lambda=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\lambda_{k}italic_λ = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The final loss is 𝒥⁢(θ)=𝒥AWSM⁢(θ)+α⁢𝒥CE⁢(θ)𝒥𝜃subscript𝒥AWSM𝜃𝛼subscript𝒥CE𝜃\mathcal{J}(\theta)=\mathcal{J}_{\text{AWSM}}(\theta)+\alpha\mathcal{J}_{\text% {CE}}(\theta)caligraphic_J ( italic_θ ) = caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT AWSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) + italic_α caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT CE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ); α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is a balancing coefficient.

5 Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we analyze the statistical properties of AWSM estimator of univariate Hawkes process. Similar conclusions also hold for the WSM estimator of Poisson process, as discussed in Section C.5. We consider M𝑀Mitalic_M i.i.d. sequences {t1(m),…,tNm(m)}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑚…superscriptsubscript𝑡subscript𝑁𝑚𝑚𝑚1𝑀\{t_{1}^{(m)},\ldots,t_{N_{m}}^{(m)}\}_{m=1}^{M}{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from p⁢(𝒯)𝑝𝒯p(\mathcal{T})italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) of a Hawkes process. We assume the true density is in the family of the model density, denoted as p⁢(𝒯)=pθ∗⁢(𝒯)𝑝𝒯subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝒯p(\mathcal{T})=p_{\theta^{*}}(\mathcal{T})italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ), where θ∗∈Θ⊂ℝrsuperscript𝜃Θsuperscriptℝ𝑟\theta^{*}\in\Theta\subset\mathbb{R}^{r}italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ roman_Θ ⊂ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The estimate θ^^𝜃\hat{\theta}over^ start_ARG italic_θ end_ARG is obtained by θ^=arg⁢minθ∈Θ⁡𝒥^AWSM⁢(θ)^𝜃subscriptargmin𝜃Θsubscript^𝒥AWSM𝜃\hat{\theta}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta\in\Theta}\hat{\mathcal{J}}_{% \text{AWSM}}(\theta)over^ start_ARG italic_θ end_ARG = start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_min end_OPERATOR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ ∈ roman_Θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG caligraphic_J end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT AWSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) where 𝒥^AWSMsubscript^𝒥AWSM\hat{\mathcal{J}}_{\text{AWSM}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_J end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT AWSM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the empirical loss. Below we omit the subscript AWSM as it does not cause any ambiguity.

5.1 Asymptotic Property

We first establish the consistency of θ^^𝜃\hat{\theta}over^ start_ARG italic_θ end_ARG for a Hawkes process.

Theorem 5.1.

Under mild regularity Assumptions C.1, C.2 and C.3, we have θ^→𝑝θ∗𝑝→^𝜃superscript𝜃\hat{\theta}\xrightarrow{p}\theta^{*}over^ start_ARG italic_θ end_ARG start_ARROW overitalic_p → end_ARROW italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as M→∞→𝑀M\rightarrow\inftyitalic_M → ∞.

5.2 Non-asymptotic Error Bound

Then, we establish a non-asymptotic error bound for θ^^𝜃\hat{\theta}over^ start_ARG italic_θ end_ARG. We define

𝒥𝐡⁢(θ)subscript𝒥𝐡𝜃\displaystyle\mathcal{J}_{\mathbf{h}}(\theta)caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) =𝔼p⁢(𝒯)⁢[∑n=1NT[12⁢ψθ2⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)+∂ψθ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)∂tn⏟An⁢(𝒯,θ)]⁢hn⁢(𝒯)+ψθ⁢(tn|ℱtn−1)⏟Bn⁢(𝒯,θ)⁢∂hn⁢(𝒯)∂tn].absentsubscript𝔼𝑝𝒯delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑇delimited-[]subscript⏟12subscriptsuperscript𝜓2𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝜓𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝐴𝑛𝒯𝜃subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯subscript⏟subscript𝜓𝜃conditionalsubscript𝑡𝑛subscriptℱsubscript𝑡𝑛1subscript𝐵𝑛𝒯𝜃subscriptℎ𝑛𝒯subscript𝑡𝑛\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{p(\mathcal{T})}\left[\sum_{n=1}^{N_{T}}\big{[}% \underbrace{\frac{1}{2}\psi^{2}_{\theta}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})+\frac{% \partial\psi_{\theta}(t_{n}|\mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})}{\partial t_{n}}}_{A_{n}(% \mathcal{T},\theta)}\big{]}h_{n}(\mathcal{T})+\underbrace{\psi_{\theta}(t_{n}|% \mathcal{F}_{t_{n-1}})}_{B_{n}(\mathcal{T},\theta)}\frac{\partial h_{n}(% \mathcal{T})}{\partial t_{n}}\right].= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_T ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ under⏟ start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_ψ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG ∂ italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T , italic_θ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_T ) + under⏟ start_ARG italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n -
